The purpose of proof

We have seen that mathematical proof is key in developing new mathematical techniques and argument. However there are several other reasons that proof is key to maths.

Proof is used:

  • To convince the reader of the truth or falsity of a given statement. This becomes particularly important when the result of the statement seems counterintuitive. This is a far more common occurrence in maths than one would initially expect.
  • To understand how and why the different assumptions, definitions and hypotheses interact and combine to make the result.
  • To communicate new ideas or Theorems. Mathematicians talk the language of proof, it is the cornerstone of mathematical discourse and debate.
  • To discover new ideas and new mathematics. This is the process of mathematical research.

A proof is an example of deductive reasoning, we begin at some starting point, under some assumptions often taking the form of definitions or statements, we then apply a sequence of mathematical or logical steps to arrive at a conclusion which is another mathematical statement.
